questions.text: Which of the following is a parasympathomimetic and miotic drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pilocarpine Pilocarpine is a parasympathomimetic drug that contracts longitudinal muscles of CB and opens spaces in the trabecular meshwork, thereby mechanically increasing aqueous flow, and hence is used in glaucoma.

Highyeild:

Indications: POAG Acute angle closure glaucoma Chronic synechiae angle closure glaucoma

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Timolol: It is a nonselective beta-1 and beta-2 blocker. It is available as 0.25% and 0.5% eye drops. Option: B. Prazosin: Prazosin inhibits the postsynaptic alpha-1 adrenoceptors. This inhibition blocks the vasoconstricting (narrowing) effect of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine) on the vessels, leading to peripheral blood vessel dilation. Option: D. Phenylephrine: Epinephrine. This direct-acting sympathomimetic drug stimulates both alpha and beta-adrenergic receptors. Preparations: It is available as 0.5%, 1 %, and 2% eye drops

Extraedge:

Contraindications: Inflammatory glaucoma Malignant glaucoma It is not preferred in young patients because it causes spasms of accommodation and miosis , which are not well tolerated in most old patients .hence, it is not used as a first or second line of management in glaucoma. It can be used as an adjuvant with other drugs

questions.text: Aniseikonia is corrected with which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contact Lens Aniseikonia is a condition wherein the two Images projected to the visual cortex from the two retinas are abnormally unequal in size and shape. Aniseikonic glasses, contact lenses, or intraocular lenses correct optical aniseikonia .

Highyeild:

Aniseikonia is a condition wherein the two Images projected to the visual cortex from the two retinas are abnormally unequal in size and shape. Etiological types- Optical aniseikonia may occur due to either inherent or acquired anisometropia of a high degree may occur due to either intrinsic or acquired anisometropia of a high degree, may develop due to displacement of retinal elements towards the nodal point in one eye due to stretching or edema of the retina Cortical aniseikonia implies asymmetrical simultaneous perception despite the equal size of Images formed on the two retina Clinical types- Symmetrical aniseikonia Spherical Image may be magnified or modified equally in both meridians. Cylindrical, Images magnified or minified symmetrically in one meridian. Asymmetrical aniseikonia Prismatic- in this Image, the difference increases progressively in one direction Pincushion- in this Image, distortion increases gradually in both directions, as seen with high plus correction in aphasia Barrel distortion- in this Image, distortion decreases slowly in both directions, as seen with high minus correction Oblique distortion- in this size of Image is the same, but there occurs a diagonal distortion of the shape Symptoms Asthenopia Diplopia Difficulty in depth perception.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Cylindrical lens: Useful in the correction of Astigmatism. Option C. Prism: Useful in the discipline of squints. Option D. Galileo telescope: Nowadays, the Galilean telescope design is only used in low-power binoculars. Keplerian and Galilean telescopes are both examples of refractors where lenses are used to collect and focus light. Nowadays, all large telescopes are reflectors where curved mirrors, rather than lenses, are used.

Extraedge:

Treatment Optical aniseikonia corrected by aniseikonic glasses, contact lenses or intraocular lens.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the ophthalmoscopy done by the instrument shown in the Image?

options.label: A
options.text: Area of the field in focus is two disc diameters

options.label: B
options.text: The Image produced is real and inverted

questions.correct_answer: B. The Image produced is real and inverted
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The Image produced is real and inverted The binocular indirect ophthalmoscope , or indirect ophthalmoscope , is an optical instrument worn on the examiner's head and sometimes attached to spectacles to inspect the fundus or back of the eye. Light reflected from the retina passes through the lens, creating a natural, horizontally, and laterally inverted Image of the fundus between the lens and the examiner. It produces a stereoscopic Image with between 2x and 5x magnification .

Highyeild:

OPHTHALMOSCOPY: It is of two major types: Direct ophthalmoscopy has an upright image of approximately 15 times magnification. Indirect ophthalmoscopy produces an inverted or reversed, natural image of 2 to 5 times magnification Features Direct ophthalmoscopy Indirect ophthalmoscope Condensing lens Not Required Required Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length Image Virtual, erect Real, inverted Illumination Not as bright; not valuable for hazy media Bright; useful for cloudy media Area of the field in focus About two disc diameters About eight disc diameters Stereopsis Absent Present Accessible fundus view Slightly beyond equator Up to Ora serrata, i.e., peripheral retina Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Area of the field in focus is two disc diameters: It is a feature of direct ophthalmoscopy; in indirect ophthalmoscopy, the Area of the field in direction is eight disc diameters. Option: C. Condensing lens is not required: it is necessary for indirect ophthalmoscopy. Option: D. Stereopsis is absent: Stereopsis is present in indirect ophthalmoscopy.

questions.correct_answer: A. The tear film can wet the condition shown in the figure.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The tear film can wet the condition shown in the figure. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Vitamin A deficiency leading to the formation of Bitot spot, as seen in the Image. These spots are characterized by small, triangular, white patches on the outer and inner sides of the cornea and covered by a material resembling dried foam , which is not wet by the tears .

Highyeild:

“CLASSIFICATION OF XEROPHTHALMIA.” Abbreviation Form of xeropthalmia XN Night blindness in children ΧΙΑ Conjunctival xerosis XIB Bitot's spots X2 Corneal xerosis X3A Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia < 1/3 corneal surface X3B Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia > 1/3 corneal surface XS Corneal Scar XF Xerophthalmic fundus PXN Maternal night blindness * Adapted from Sommer Alfred, 1995

A similar condition associated with night blindness (nyctalopia) is found in marasmic children and is associated with keratomalacia and necrosis of the cornea . Option: C. Local treatment consists in relieving the dryness with artificial tears and mucomimetic agents . In the vitamin A deficiency variety, nutrition should be restored by administering vitamin A along with these symptomatic management modalities .

questions.text: Azithromycin prophylaxis is indicated in a place when the prevalence of trachoma follicles is more than what percentage in age group < 9yrs:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10% Current WHO recommendations for antibiotic treatment of trachoma are as follows: Determine the district-level prevalence of follicular trachoma in 1- to 9-year-old children. If the majority is 10% or higher, conduct mass treatment with all people throughout the district with antibiotics. If the majority is less than 10%, conduct an assessment at the sub-district or community level in areas of known disease. If assessment at the sub-district or community level is undertaken in sub-districts or communities where the prevalence of follicular trachoma in 1- to 9-year-old children is 10% or more, conduct mass treatment of all people with antibiotics. If assessment at the sub-district or community level is undertaken in sub-districts or communities where the prevalence of follicular trachoma in 1- to 9-year-old children is 5% or more but less than 10% , targeted treatment should be considered. Targeted treatment could involve identifying and treating all members of any family in which one or more members have follicular trachoma. Suppose the sub-district or community level assessment is undertaken in sub-districts or communities where the prevalence of follicular trachoma in 1- to 9-year-old children is less than 5%. Antibiotic distribution may not be necessary in that case, though targeted treatment can be considered.

Highyeild:

Antibiotics for prevention against trachoma (Secondary prevention). The use of antibiotics constitutes the secondary prevention against trachoma. Current WHO recommendations for community-based mass antibiotic therapy in endemic areas are as below: In areas with 10% or more prevalence of active trachoma (TF in children 1-9 years): Oral azithromycin (single dose of 20 mg/ kg up to 1 g) should be administered to all community members. Tetracycline eye ointment twice daily for six weeks is recommended for all pregnant women, children six months, and those allergic to macrolides. Note. Mass antibiotic therapy should be given once a year for three straight years, after which a reassessment of prevalence should be made. The annual treatment should be continued till the TF prevalence in 1-9 years children of that area becomes less than 5%. In areas with a prevalence between more than 5% and less than 10% , targeted antibiotic therapy is recommended only among family members and close contacts of the patients. In areas with a prevalence of less than 5%, treatment of the patients only is recommended.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. 0.08: In areas with a prevalence between more than 5% and less than 10% , targeted antibiotic therapy is recommended only among family members and close contacts of the patients. Option: C . 0.06: In areas with a prevalence between more than 5% and less than 10% , targeted antibiotic therapy is recommended only among family members and close contacts of the patients. Option: D . 0.04: In areas with a prevalence of less than 5%, treatment of the patients only is recommended.

Extraedge:

Safe strategy The WHO's GET 2020 program (Global Elimination of Trachoma by 2020) has adopted the so-called SAFE approach for prophylaxis against trachoma infection and prevention of blindness. The SAFE strategy includes S: Surgery (Tertiary prevention), A: Antibiotic use (Secondary prevention), F: Facial hygiene (Primary prevention), and E: Environmental changes (Primordial prevention).

questions.text: A 23-year-old female came in with red eyes and tears. On examination, minute stellate scars were seen with the slit lamp. Artificial tear drops were given, and she was sent home. A week later, she came back due to the increased severity of symptoms along with lacrimation and photophobia. On examination, you notice conjunctival congestion, papillary enlargement, and the development of follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva, as seen in the image below. The finding of rounded, depressed regions of necrotic limbal follicles which were seen in this patient is termed:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herbert’s PITS Herbert pits: Follicle-like infiltrations appear near the limbus (Herbert pits). The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of trachoma. Trachoma is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A, B, and C . It is mainly associated with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge. When chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia, later blurring, and finally severe loss of vision. Signs include conjunctival congestion, papillary enlargement, and the development of follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva.

Highyeild:

McCallan's classification divided the clinical course of the trachoma into four stages: Stage I (Incipient trachoma or stage of infiltration ). It is characterized by hyperemia of the palpebral conjunctiva and immature follicles. Stage II (Established trachoma or stage of florid infiltration ). It is characterized by the appearance of mature follicles, papillae, and progressive corneal pannus. Stage Ill (Cicatrising trachoma or stage of scarring ). It includes noticeable scarring of the palpebral conjunctiva. Stage IV (Healed trachoma or stage of sequelae ). The disease is quiet and cured, but sequelae due to cicatrization, give rise to symptoms

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. The von Arlt line is linear subconjunctival scarring seen on the upper tarsus in “burned-out" trachoma. Option: C. Fuchs' spots are areas of punched-out chorioretinal atrophy in the maculae of high myopes . Option: D. Horner-Trantas dots are pathognomonic for vernal keratoconjunctivitis . Horner-Trantas dots rarely last longer than a week from their initial presentation and generally resolve rapidly with the initiation of topical corticosteroid therapy.

questions.text: A patient with conjunctivitis presented with smooth, pale, pink-to-yellow, elevated lesions surrounded by displaced vessels. These lesions are typically more severe inferiorly than superiorly except for:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trachoma. Follicles: Hyperplasia of lymphoid tissue Generally seen in viral or chlamydial conditions Smooth, pale, pink-to-yellow, elevated lesions surrounded by displaced vessels Trachoma is nearly always a disease of the superior conjunctiva. This is in stark contrast to inclusion conjunctivitis, another chlamydial disease, which is more severe inferiorly. Toxic follicular conjunctivitis secondary to medications and viral keratoconjunctivitis are also more severe.

Highyeild:

Ocular Infections caused by Chlamydia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Chlamydia inclusion conjunctivitis is generally spread by sexual transmission from a genital reservoir of infection. In adults, the organism may be transferred from the genitals by the fingers, but a common mode of infection is through the water in swimming pools; thus, the disease may occur in local epidemics (swimming pool conjunctivitis). It is also commonly transmitted from the mother to the newborn when follicle formation is less evident. Inclusion conjunctivitis is characteristically acute at the onset. The incubation period varies from 5 to 10 days. The follicular hypertrophy is always more prominent in the lower lid than in the upper, although in acute cases, the follicles may be partially obscured by papillary hypertrophy. The exudate, composed principally of neutrophils, may be moderately abundant. The cornea is involved in a superficial punctate keratitis Option: B. Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC) is a type of acute follicular conjunctivitis mostly associated with superficial punctate keratitis and usually occurs in epidemics, hence the name EKC. Pseudomembrane lining the lower fornix and palpebral conjunctiva may be formed in about 3 percent patients with severe inflammation. Follicles of small to moderate size, typically involving the lower fornix and palpebral conjunctiva, form the characteristic feature. Option: D. Parinaud oculoglandular syndrome is a rare condition of chronic low-grade fever, unilateral granulomatous conjunctivitis as seen in the figure with surrounding follicles, and ipsilateral regional (preauricular) lymphadenopathy. It is synonymous with cat scratch disease, although several other causes have been implicated, including tularaemia, insect hairs (ophthalmia nodosa), Treponema Pallidum, sporotrichosis, tuberculosis, and acute C. trachomatis infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male has been diagnosed with trachoma. Match the following statements with the findings in this patient’s condition. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

I-c, II-b, III-a At a later stage of trachoma , trachomatous pannus develops as a lymphoid infiltration with vascularization of the margin of the cornea, usually limited to the upper half as seen in the figure but tending to spread towards the centre and to involve the whole cornea. The upper part of the margin of the cornea becomes cloudy, and minute superficial vessels, springing from the corneal loops, grow inwards towards the centre. Progressive pannus In progressive pannus, the vessels are mostly parallel to each other and directed vertically downwards, anastomosing little. They extend to a level which forms a horizontal line, beyond which there is a narrow strip of infiltration and haze. Regressive pannus In regressive pannus, the infiltration shows evidence of receding so that the vessels extend a short distance beyond the infiltrated and hazy area. This difference is useful in estimating the results of treatment. Corneal ulcers Corneal ulcers, which may be chronic, occur anywhere but are commonest at the advancing edge of the pannus. They are shallow, a little infiltrated, and cause much lacrimation and photophobia. The pannus may resolve completely, leaving the cornea quite clear apart from the obliterated vessels if treated early, when the pannus has not destroyed Bowman's membrane.

Highyeild:

Grading of trachoma McCallan's classification divided the clinical course of the trachoma into four stages: Stage I (Incipient trachoma or stage of infiltration) . It is characterized by hyperaemia of the palpebral conjunctiva and immature follicles. Stage II (Established trachoma or stage of florid infiltration) . It is characterized by the appearance of mature follicles, papillae and progressive corneal pannus. Stage III (Cicatrising trachoma or stage of scarring) . It includes obvious scarring of the palpebral conjunctiva. Stage IV (Healed trachoma or stage of sequelae) . The disease is quiet and cured, but sequelae due to cicatrisation give rise to symptoms.

questions.text: All of the following are corneal signs of trachoma except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ant's line Conjunctiva/ scarring, which may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear . Linear scar present in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt's line, not Ant’s line.

Highyeild:

Corneal signs (Phase of active trachoma) Superficial keratitis may be present in the upper part. Herbert follicles refer to typical follicles present in the limbal area (histologically, these are similar to conjunctival follicles. ) Progressive pannus , i.e., infiltration of the cornea associated with vascularization, is seen in the upper part. The vessels are superficial and lie between the epithelium and Bowman's membrane . Later on , Bowman's membrane is also destroyed. Pannus in active trachoma is progressive in which infiltration of the cornea is ahead of vascularization Corneal sign (Phase of cicatricial trachoma) Regressive pannus (pannus siccus), in which vessels extend a short distance beyond the infiltration area. Herbert pits are the oval or circular pitted scars left after the healing of Herbert follicles in the limbal area. Corneal opacity may be present in the upper part. It may even extend down and involve the papillary area. It is the result of trachomatous corneal lesions. Other corneal sequelae may be corneal ectasia, corneal xerosis, and total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Herbed Pits: Herbert pits are the oval or circular pitted scars left after healing of Herbert follicles in the limbal area Option: B . Pannus: Progressive pannus , i.e., infiltration of the cornea associated with vascularization, is seen in the upper part. The vessels are superficial and lie between the epithelium and Bowman's membrane . Later on , Bowman's membrane is also destroyed. Pannus in active trachoma is progressive in which infiltration of the cornea is ahead of vascularization Option: C . Opacity: Corneal opacity may be present in the upper part. It may even extend down and involve the papillary area. It is the result of trachomatous corneal lesions.

Extraedge:

World Health Organization has identified five stages in the development of trachoma Inflammation — follicular. The infection is just beginning at this stage . Five or more follicles — small bumps that contain lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell — are visible with magnification on the inner surface of your upper eyelid (conjunctiva). Inflammation — intense. In this stage, your eye is highly infectious and becomes irritated, with a thickening or swelling of the upper eyelid. Eyelid scarring. Repeated infections lead to scarring of the inner eyelid. The scars often appear as white lines when examined with magnification. Your eyelid may become distorted and may turn into (entropion). Ingrown eyelashes (trichiasis). The scarred inner lining of your eyelid continues to deform, causing your lashes to turn in so that they rub on and scratch the transparent outer surface of your eye (cornea). Corneal clouding. The cornea becomes affected by an inflammation that is most commonly seen under your upper lid. Continual inflammation compounded by scratching from the in-turned lashes leads to clouding of the cornea.
